abstract.para: MobilityDB is an extension to the PostgreSQL object-relational database system and its spatial extension PostGIS. It allows temporal and spatio-temporal objects to be stored in the database, that is, objects whose attribute values and/or location evolves in time. MobilityDB includes functions for analysis and processing of temporal and spatio-temporal objects and provides support for GiST and SP-GiST indexes.

chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: MobilityDB is an extension of PostgreSQL and PostGIS that provides temporal types. Such types are data types that represent the evolution on time of values of some element type, called the base type of the temporal type. For instance, temporal integers may be used to represent the evolution on time of the number of employees of a department. In this case, the data type is “temporal integer” and “integer” is the base type. Similarly, a temporal float may be used to represent the evolution on time of the temperature of a room. As another example, a temporal point may be used to represent the evolution on time of the location of a car, as reported by GPS devices. Temporal types are useful because representing values that evolve in time is essential in many applications, for example in mobility applications. Furthermore, the operators on the base types (such as arithmetic operators and aggregation for integers and floats, spatial relationships and distance for geometries) can be intuitively generalized when the values evolve in time.

MobilityDB provides the following temporal types: tbool, tint, tfloat, ttext, tgeompoint and tgeogpoint. These temporal types are based, respectively, on the bool, int, float, and text base types provided by PostgreSQL, and on the geometry and geography base types provided by PostGIS (restricted to 2D or 3D points).
Although 4D temporal points can be represented, the M dimension is currently not taken into account. Furthermore, MobilityDB uses four time types to represent extents of time: the timestamptz type provided by PostgreSQL and three new types which are period, timestampset, and periodset. In addition, two range types are defined in MobilityDB: intrange and floatrange.

sect1.title: Workshop Materials
sect1.para:
This workshop uses a data package. Download it and extract to a convenient location. There are two types of data in the package:
GIS data from Berlin extracted from OpenStreetMap. It includes the road network and points of interest.
Mobility data generated with BerlinMOD, a benchmark for spatio-temporal database management systems. BerlinMOD provides a data generation that can be customized. The data in the package has been generated over the OSM road network for Berlin at a scale factor of 0.005.

All the data in the package is public domain and freely redistributable. All the software used in the workshop is open source, and freely redistributable. This workshop is licensed as Creative Commons share alike with attribution, and is freely redistributable under the terms of that license.
This workshop is heavily inspired from and builds upon the workshop Introduction to PostGIS. This workshop assumes therefore that you have a knowledge of GIS in general and PostGIS in particular.
